They are using a loading dock as a paint booth to paint vehicles. The "paint booth" has standard exhaust fans with no filters, spraying paint chemicals into the atmosphere going directly into a watershed area, coating the plants, ground and trees. The paint waste/lacquor thinner is sprayed out of the gun through the fans, on the ground etc.. They have no collection for any of the paint waste. They wash the dust/overspray out of the room with a hose that goes to a drain in the room and exits the rear of the building directly into the water streams. The paint mixing area has no mixing room or ventilation exposing the workers to dangerous fumes. The building has other fans(roof, walls) with no filters to ventilate other chemicals out of the building. Workers are constantly exposed to cancerous fumes inside and outside of the building from welding, sanding, paint dust, mixing, painting and glue.

complaint:
egregious development by TPA Residential .  I have been living adjacent to a nightmarish and non stop assault on my quality of life for 15 months  and NOW?  It's even worse and STILL no end in sight. Originally, when they publicized the plans they claimed the entire project including vertical buildings would be finished by June of '24.  They won't even be finished with the mitigation by then.  
They are taking absolutely NO care to keep the toxic dust and dirt out of the air and it is floating around the area coating everything, including my home and car.  When I approached the site manager the other day and asked instead of crushing the old concrete slabs through a grinder making horrible noise and spewing toxins into the air why don't they haul it all out and crush it in a waste disposal area,  he denied it was happening, said "It's too expensive" So in other words, we are creating a  high decibel, highly stressful atmosphere and spewing toxins  all over  a residential area and then  dismissed me, told me to get off the property and that he would not discuss it.  
I have not been able to use my property during the day outside since August of '22 due to the noise, stench and toxic nature of the site where old homes full of asbestos and lead paint and cars and who knows what else was dumped there.  I can literally feel grit and dirt on my face if I have to go out in my yard for any reason.  And it still stinks out there at night most of the time. 
I probably have the worst of it, given that my property is on the corner closest to the operation with both front and back yards facing it, but it's affecting people across, along both sides of the block.  
It's become inhumane and abusive and made my lovely home a hell hole.  And TPA does not care whatsoever.  They lied from the beginning about the scope of this project to keep people from standing up against it. Either that or they are catastrophically incompetent, which is as bad.  And NOT ONE TIME, has ANYONE offered me ANY compensation for the LOSS of the use of my property, for the stress, for the dirt and dust all over my pergola, my porch, my outdoor furniture, my care. EVERY SINGLE DAY. 

They sent these smiling young representatives over in the early summer of 2020

to show us all the wonderful plans for the location and said NOTHING about the mitigation, although I knew from a neighbor that there would be some.  And when they did get it started and it was evident that this was really bad, they lied about how long it would go on. John Jensen, The project manager said to my face that it would be completed no later than March of '23, which in October of '22 when he said it, sounded horrible. 5 more MONTHS of this?!!! That's a dream now. 

This disgusting glossing over of it that everyone's values will increase because of it while they are destroying our rights to some quality of life for YEARS, is no comfort.  I would GLADLY give that up to have avoided this monstrous and corrupt profiteering at the expense of the surrounding community.  
Here are some photos and videos to support that they are unleashing toxic dust all over everyone. Enjoy the rattling, roaring, banging, clanging, beeping.  The windshield is my car the day after I washed it. That's what it's like almost every day.
IMAGINE LIVING WITH THIS 6 DAYS A WEEK ALL DAY FOR 2 YEARS.  THEN IT WILL BE AT LEAST  ANOTHER 1.5 YEARS OF VERTICAL CONSTRUCTION.  WHO APPROVED THIS?

Follow up to above referenced complaint: CTS 102802
It is now several months since this initial complaint and as I suspected, the business is now once again exhausting fumes that have a very strong odor and are causing me to be nauseous in my own yard and home.  I would ask that you send a different investigator who will actually perform a thorough investigation on these toxic fumes. 
 

The following is a draft of an email that I composed, but never sent with the hopeful expectation this matter was resolved. Clearly, it is not:

    I would invite each of you to review the complaint, and the subsequent report/investigation of my complaint. It was my hope that you would find no toxic chemicals and put at ease my mind and concerns over what I and my neighbors are inhaling. 
After reviewing the report online, I spoke with Mr. Mark Peake this morning in regards to his investigation and report. Unfortunately, this did very little to ease my concerns. 

As stated in the report and confirmed in our conversation this morning, he did no actual monitoring or testing of the emissions from the building. The fan was not running. Fumes were not being exhausted. He did not specify, approve or audit the source of the emissions.
 He did not physically inspect the chemicals being used. He conducted a cursory tour of the property and subsequently allowed the owners to self report on the amounts and types of chemicals being used. 
In addition, he allowed them to self report on the data sheets and provide them to him in a delayed response a week or two later.
 In my opinion, this was little more than a telephone interview could have accomplished, not a thorough investigation.

And as of today, miraculously, the fan is once again running, and exhausting fumes, which have absolutely no odor at all.  Imagine that!
I am certainly pleased to report that I am not inhaling nauseous fumes. However, I do not consider this matter closed, and I am highly concerned that it will continue once the owners believe they are no longer being monitored. 
In addition, Mr. Peake found it necessary to reprimand me when I inquired as to a valid permit for this business. He stated the owners are not required to have a permit for any air quality emissions and the business was allowed there long before this residential neighborhood was built. I would invite him or you to verify those comments. My home was built in the 1930s. This neighborhood was platted and developed before that time and I know for a fact that business has not been operational for 90 years. 


I submitted a simple request to my government agency after speaking with the owner multiple times over the course of 5 years about the condition of the property, and he refused with a sly grin to participate in any type of voluntary cleanup.
 I have even suggested that a baffle be placed on the building to direct those fumes up rather than directly into my residence.
 I’m not asking for his livelihood to be affected. I’m asking for a simple, commonsense remedy so that we can all live without toxic air in our homes.

This is in reference to Faircloth Forest Products "Air Permit",  that was run in The Blade.  Let me begin by saying that THE CLEAN AIR ACT protects health and welfare from different types of air pollution.  This mill is already not following the act and with growth and additions, it will comply even less.  Our property is approximately 300 yards from this saw mill and we deal with the air pollution daily!  There are many problems that already affect us daily with existing mill without the approval of additions that you seem to want to approve.  The noise level is already unbearable at most times and it has taken away all of our peace and tranquility.  We can not enjoy being at home for all the NOISE!  At the same time, we are dealing with fallout from the mill such as smoke/smog settling down on us and constant sour smells.  There is a loud humming noise from the pellet mill that has increased as well.  Also this year, we have an additional problem of wood chips (sawdust) falling on our property, particularly our vehicles.  They have been covered with this fallout and I have advised a lawyer in Swainsboro along with pictures as documentation.  Our car detailer has told us that this residue will damage the paint on our vehicles!!  Keep in mind that we are breathing all this stuff into our lungs and God only knows what it is doing to our health and breathing.  We have valid concerns already with existing problems, this expansion will add to the levels of gases and different chemicals being released into the air and providing even greater damage to our health.  I know that you state this will be monitored, but I think these reports should be published and mailed to neighbors of the mill.

I also believe that a public hearing should be conducted to address the issues that are current and any issues the expansion may cause.  The method and frequency of monitoring should be discussed and any questions should be answered at this time.  The notice of public comment was hidden in our local paper in the middle of legal ads.  It should have been on a page in bold print so it was easily seen and should have been broadcast on our local radio station.  In addition, a personal letter should have been sent out to landowners within a 5-mile radius.  I strongly feel that I have legitimate concerns that need to be addressed.  It is my understanding that laws, rules and any government decisions should be fair to ALL people, not just one group pr entity.

I have particularly noticed it around my home beginning a year or two ago (maybe longer), sometimes late night and mostly early morning. Dear Mr. Williams,

I live in Rutledge Ga across Hwy 20 from the proposed Rivian site.  They have begun to grade the property.

For the last couple of days my husband and I have suffered great allergy reactions that we have not had before- ever.  It is difficult to breathe and we have been coughing and sneezing.  I know ragweed is blooming as well as goldenrod, but this is not from that.  The dust surrounding our property is off the charts.  It looks like we are living in a cloud of smoke.

I don’t know what can be done, but we cannot live in these conditions and from what I hear, it’s just begun.  We have animals and chickens that seem to be reacting as well.

I hope you can help in some way.

Sincerely,
Chris Grace

Yesterday seems to have been the first big day of major work on the Rivian site, particularly in the Morgan County portion.  Apparently, the self-reporting responsibility and the Walton County monitoring responsibility isn’t working to well.  We have reports from residents and passersby of huge dust clouds, causing breathing problems, eye irritation, dirt and dust within homes and on vehicles, filthy swimming pools.  One person contacted me and said the horses at a horse farm on 278, adjacent to the project, were grazing in one of these dust clouds.  This has all come from the huge clouds of dirt, dust, dried grass and hay that is in the air.  Apparently they have equipment scraping the ground, loading the earth into dump trucks and hauling it to one spot elsewhere on the property where it is being dumped.  (When we get the rain that is predicted for next week there will be a huge mud pile)

Please address this problem this morning or today and/or tell us what else to do.  Should we be contacting anybody else?

Thank you,
JoEllen Artz

Dear Mr. Williams,  

I’m contacting you in regulars to the fact there is ongoing grading in rural Rutledge Georgia as of this week billowing tons of red dust into the air. 

There was a recent court ruling against the JDA and the State regarding a bond they were requesting for RIVIAN to be built here. The court ruled with the citizens and against the State and JDA. 

In court, both the representative for the State and the JDA stated, without this bond, this project cannot go forward. 

We in opposition, mainly because of the environmental issues that a 20 million sq ft MEGA Industrial Auto Plant, 7 stories high on 2003 acres in a RURAL agricultural zoned area, will cause irreparable damage to our community. 

This grading, in spite of what both parties swore under oath to the judge about the bond denial “killing the deal”, is a slap in the face of the court and the citizens here in opposition. 

We are well dependent, this grading and the fact we are all well dependent here, is unacceptable! Water is already an issue here. My husband and I have in the past, had our own well go dry. We could not afford a drilled well so we had to pay for another dug well far from the dry well and the cost to run pipe back to our house, was as much or more than the well. 

Our Morgan County Comprehensive Use Plan, 2017-2036 states this land and all around it will remain agricultural through 2036. We citizens who live, work, farm, own small businesses here, are the ones who approved that plan. We depended on people, we had trusted to implement that plan through its full term and theirs, but they did not. 

Those on the JDA and Morgan County Board of Commissioners who were supposed to represent our area in this county, some developed their own legacy farmland (one, the former JDA chairman serving then, resigned, before he was paid a great profit, (20 times the going price per acre here) for that same legacy farmland, saying “because it wouldn’t look right if he was still chairman” when his families good name and legacy farmland was sold out and paid for. (All public record) 

The JDA threw this project to the state by letter overnight (again public record) when citizens were finally told RIVIAN was coming to Rutledge and it was already a “Done Deal”. There was no transparency! Everything done on this “closed door deal” for years, had been hidden in secret, under NDAs. The first any citizen (not involved) knew about this, was when the Governor announced on TV Dec 16, 2021 that RIVIAN (the company the state had already purchased the Industrial site for, near Savannah) where they have placed Hyundai recently. Instead RIVIAN (a risky financial EV start up) would be put on our legacy farmland zoned Agricultural, being actively farmed (the last hay was just cut recently).  

After the project was thrown to the state by the JDA, stating by letter “this project (they developed) is too big for us to handle, the Gov took it over for the State, the next day. 

The rezoning meeting, our ONE chance to express our environmental and other concerns, was cancelled! And the rezoning from agricultural until 2036, now for heavy industrial use by the State, the sign came down. 

We in Rutledge, with Hard Labor Creek State Park and UGA’s Observatory placed here intentionally, because of lack of light pollution, will no longer be able to operate and use their brand new telescope. 

Camp Twin Lakes where I volunteer in summers as “nurse Pam” for our special needs children, is in sight of this area. It like the Observatory, was placed here for a reason. Clean air and clean well water. The twin lakes the special children fish in and row in, not to mention the peace and quiet a camp like this needs, will all be taken away. 

Our abundant wild life including the American Bald Eagle that soars overhead after making a comeback here, will all be in danger! The barn swallow nests are abundant here. They build every year on my front porch and in barns and at houses all around. Deer are plentiful here along with many other species. Squirrels, including black fox squirrels, birds of ever color, we have it all! For now. The Georgia Audubon Society was already aware of RIVIAN early on in this process and we’re concerned about it’s impact here.

Please, I beg you, if there is anything the State EPD and/or DNR can do to help us here and save our legacy farmland and wildlife habitat, it will be most appreciated. The DNR building and fish hatchery are in this same area of the proposed plant, on Hwy 278 in neighboring Walton Co. We never had a voice, because there was no transparency here and we didn’t know anything of the magnitude of this plant, heading our way. Please be our voice now! 

I have a picture of the Bald Eagle in a tree on Centennial Road, taken recently by my husband’s cousin. A road with no exit or entrance now, about to be changed. It’s exit’s and entrances will feed onto a five lane access Road, running adjacent to I 20. 

I have concerns about all these things and more. I have concerns about where all this displaced wildlife will go. I have concerns about our special kids at Camp Twin Lakes who just returned this year after missing two years of eligibility to this camp, because of the Pandemic. 

That is their only time they are away from home, at no charge to their parents. A magical place where all their outdoor dreams can come true! A chance to spend a week with other children like themselves out of doors, with nature and do what other more able bodied children take for granted at summer camps. One on one ratio camper to counselor, volunteer nurses, firefighters, EMTS make this possible, along with our sponsors. 

During the past two years, with generous donations from sponsors, Camp Twin Lakes has doubled its size! Prepared to open the new section soon and serve twice as many special needs children as ever before. We celebrated our 30th year with MDA Camp there in July of this year. Please don’t let it be our children's last! They have fragile conditions such as muscular dystrophy, diabetes, cancer, skin disease and so much more. They can’t be exposed to contaminants in air and water, or the noise and light pollution. 

When we Rutledge citizens finally found out on TV RIVIAN was coming, we started attending as many JDA meetings as we could, trying to have an opportunity to express ALL our many concerns. 

At one of those many meetings we attended early on, the JDAs own expert admitted our water table, the loss of multiple ponds on this land as well as our three best natural streams to be covered over with dirt and buried under 2003 acres of concrete and asphalt, would all be affected. Greatest fear, our wells! The expert also said lakes and streams from here at HLC State Park, Camp Twin Lakes next door, on down to Lake Sinclair and Lake Oconee would be adversely affected. We heard him! 

No EPD studies have been shown to us. One meeting for citizen input on design and EPD issues, held in Monroe, Walton Co turned out to be only a “flack taker” meeting. The panel had no answers for our questions and concerns. No plan or designs to even show us for input on. No EPD studies had been done and no permits had been applied for. 

It seems once the State of Georgia took over the project, our legacy farmland, the need for normal ways for citizens to have any input, checks and balances here on zoning and other issues, were all taken away. 

After our prescient setting win in court denying the bond came down, it now seems nothing has changed! With the drought we are experiencing no consideration for us in that. Grading was to start on this past Monday, and it did! The dust is rolling, smell of pine sap is in the air, the noise pollution has begun along with the destruction and the erasure of 2003 of the most beautiful “true green” legacy farmland acres in Georgia, has begun. 

Please if you can’t stop this, and we’ve won what both parties said would “kill the deal” in court. Hiring the best EPD attorney we could find, recommended to me as one of five by our national EPD when contacted. We at the late notice we finally got, after the deal was done, have done everything agencies such as yours has recommended we do, but still the State started grading on their own previously set schedule? Again, as if we citizens and the courts and agencies that regulate these things, don’t exist! 

Can our state run completely over our rights and grade our way of life away? No matter how this was achieved and no matter what the court rules against them? 

We will lose all the green, all the trees, and all the wildlife habitat along with our only sources of clean water. We need that water for our wells we are dependent on here. Our pools that weren’t closed yet, already have a layer of red dust and reddened debris in the bottom. Our air is dusty red. Our hearts are broken but not our spirits. 

Rutledge isn’t known as “Small But Special” as just a slogan. We are special because of our community, our people and will remain so. A town with a population less than 1000 has opposition numbers 3400 strong on our #no2rivian website and Our Communities Oppose RIVIAN Assembly Plant page, on FB. Hundreds of the community filled a giant barn recently to hear from our lawyers, just before the ruling in our favor! 

If you want to see what we have, please visit these sites online or better yet, come here in person. I’d be happy to show you around! 

My husband and I own the oldest business in town, Rutledge Hardware Store built in1891 and has been in continuous operation since. We are the fourth owners of record. We have fought for the best for this community, for 42 years. We got Rutledge, as a town, on the National Register of Historic Places. 

We don’t even have a red light in town, we have a STOP barrel that the NY Times featured and called “Rutledge’s only sophisticated traffic device”. It was built by my father in law and his good friend and sanctioned by the DOT as their engineers had no solution for where to put stop signs on our corners of Main and Fairplay street. 

Rutledge Hardware sits on Fairplay Street. We live on Fairplay Road. This one move by local officials thrown to the State puts everything we have here in jeopardy. The JDA has a new sign at the exit off I 20 onto Hwy 278 on the Rutledge side. It stands exactly where I have a photo of my husbands grandmother Cassie tending her cows in 1930, on the historic Butler Place. Nothing done here by county or State, has been “Fair Play”.

That new sign with the JDA on it and put up by them, reads “East Atlanta MEGA Industrial Site”. There could not be a more unsuitable place or contrast between Grandma Cassie standing on that spot with her Jersey cows and now the JDA planting their sign there, announcing the plans they have for us. 

I don’t know about you, but to me that is the saddest thing I’ve ever seen. The JDA announcing they are not finished here, they’ve only just begun. There will be no evidence of the generations of farmers who still farm here today. There will be no home for the Bald Eagle and the thousands of other wildlife that is so abundant here now. No barns for the barn swallows to build  nests in. There will be no gently rolling green pastures or farms or clean water or star lit nights here for our observatory. By erasing our history, they, the JDA are erasing our agricultural heritage, ALWAYS and forever.

Their excuse, to create more jobs. We need more workers here, not more jobs! We need real green pastures to lie down in, not a risky start up EV Auto Plant! Look at help wanted signs and unemployment rates for our county and state. Where will 7500 workers come from? Where will they live? There aren’t locals available for these new jobs or even enough locals needing work for the two jobs for every unemployed worker here today!

I’m sorry this letter is so long and got so personal. But I’m laying my broken heart bare for you. I’m doing this to see if anyone in this state truly cares about the environment that exists here now and the needs of citizens and Camp Twin Lakes for special children. The Observatory, the farms and the families who exist here now. I pray you do. 

Sincerely, 

Pam Jones, RN 
Small business owner 
Protector of all things Rutledge for over 42 years

complaint:
Dear Karen,
Several times a week, my home and family farm is engulfed in a plume of stinky smoke with ash particulates from the neighboring poultry farm. Needless to say, this is obviously unhealthy, does not qualify as quality air to breath, and does not meet acceptable living standards. I have talked to the DNR EPD about it before, and was informed that this form of pollution was outside the scope of authority of the EPD. I was then directed to the dept of agriculture, who informed me that they only license the incinerators, do not handle the pollution caused by the incinerators or misuse of the incinerators, and then directed me back to the EPD.

What I am attempting to accomplish is to prevent my farm from being filled with smoke, and to preserve the quality of the natural resources within my farm and around it. Taking the poultry farm to court in order to receive compensation for damages undergone, is an extremely costly venture to undertake, will breed further hostility in this small community, and most importantly will not necessarily guarantee the safety of our farm from further exposure to toxins produced by the poultry farm. Homes that have been handed down from one generation to the next carry a large amount of personal attachment that cannot be compensated for through financial means. So, to file for suit against the poultry company, might be a necessary action, but not necessarily a productive one.

What I am having difficulty finding out is how are huge farms of this size exempt from following pollution guidelines that only seem decent and common place for other forms of industry? More importantly, I do not know why pollution of this nature appears to be completely uninhibited from occurring, and/or why does poultry production get the proverbial "get out of jail free" card and other less apparent forms of pollution not? To place into context, one receives a fine for littering, yet what is occurring on my farm to my family can occur without repercussions.

I know that our situation is an exception to the rule and is the result of excessiveness and not common place, but I have difficulty accepting that there is no action that can be taken to end this other than by potentially ineffective personal legal action. The EPD representative I talked with mentioned that the smoke and debris is a direct result of the farm overloading the incinerators beyond the recommended limits. This is obviously negligence, but legally can only be dealt with by seeking repayment for damages. Why is that, and is there really no agency that can put a stop to this?

Sincerely,
William Ingram

I am writing concerning several observations and questions I have regarding Sterigenics.  I believe GAEPD announced they had secured funding for an additional 6 months of air testing. There currently is another trailer parked at dock #24 since Oct 15. Please see the picture below. Again I have time/date stamped photos if you need them.

complaint:
I’m hoping you can help me with an on-going problem we are having in my neighborhood here in Columbia County.  When the adjoining property was rezoned to Manufacturing, we were assured by our local Planning Dept. that no pollution  of any kind would be allow to affect our neighboring residential properties. Now they tell me they don’t have the ability to do anything about a cabinet shop that is allowing what smells like strong paint fumes to be exhausted from their shop. At times it is so strong that we can’t stay out in our backyard. Unfortunately, we are only separated by a chain link fence. We normally leave our windows open this time of the year and let our whole house attic fan cool our house. We can’t even do that when a slight shift in the prevailing winds from the southwest brings those fumes right into the house.  Not only do I have to deal with the headaches I get from exposure to these fumes , but we now have out 1 year old grandson living with us and I am extremely worried about the effect that these VOC’s could possibly have on his development.  Is there any way that the state can check to see if they have any sort of filter on their exhaust system and if so, is it working properly ? The Environmental Compliance folks in Columbia County tell me that they are not equipped to do air monitoring and suggested I contact the EPD. 
I have attached a map showing the location of the business, Cedar Ridge Cabinet Company at 321 UN Court, as it relates to my house location at 5168 Bluegrass Trail , Grovetown, Ga. 30813 
I’m hoping if your department is not the correct group to handle this type of problem, you can point me in the right direction of who I need to contact.
I would appreciate any help that you can provide.

In the area north of Hwy 369 (Brown’s Bridge Rd) up to Jot’em Down Road. nearest WWTPs to see if they are land applying any biosolids to farmland in the area (may be available in Biosolids Management Plans).  Also maybe check with DOAg  (Jennifer Wren) to see if she is aware of anyone land applying soil amendments in the area.  Maybe we should also check with Hampton Creek WRF to make sure they are not discharging without a permit again.

I spoke with the Dept of Utilities today concerning this issue which has been going on for the last two weeks.  Apparently this is a problem that has been going on at different times during the year for years now.  I know that it was going on 21 years ago when I moved to Cumming, however, it usually doesn’t last this long and some years it is worse than others.  This year just happens to be one of the worse.  Daily it is a topic on the internet because people do not know what it is or what is going on.  The problem is the City of Cumming is apparently doing nothing to correct the problem.

Let’s get out of the way that it is not the lake and the water - that is a whole other issue which is being worked on by the utility company.  

It is Tyson or Koch, and most of the citizens know it.  Their system (that they own) located near the fairgrounds is the culprit, and it needs to be fixed.  As a resident of Cumming I should not have to put up with this because I do believe there is a solution to the problem.    If there are any type of air vents on that tank, there is probably a filtration system that would help get rid of the stench.  If in fact the problem can be fixed, Tyson needs to step up and correct it.  If they choose to ignore it the City of Cumming needs to force them to correct the problem or start enforcing a fine until it is corrected.
